body:
> it would be awesome if we could execute all of our tutorial jupyter notebooks and verify they work on each build.

sphinx/netlify currently does this for us (as long as the notebooks don't have run cells in them prior to committing)

>  It would likewise be awesome if we could store this output .ipynb file somewhere for pretty rendering of some sort, especially if we can make use of the built-in Github viewer (so we don't have to manage any of our own servers for it).

i don't know if the above puts the static markdown/html anywhere. I do know how to do that from command line, locally, im sure that process could be automated. also unsure if this is necessary given the above?
i find the github viewer is hit or miss (at times it looks great and is convenient, for larger notebooks it can puke)

issue.title: setup.py simplifications

labels.name: ndd
labels.description: tasks that may be appropriate for Neuro Data Design course

labels.name: pkg
labels.description: related to package management, github, travis, etc.

issue.body:
#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* Minor simplifications to `setup.py`.
* Fixes #422, #423, and #424

body:
> * Run flake8 or black - we should have a discussion on what black offers (I'm unfamiliar with it)

flake8 is a linter and just shows you where there are style issues. I dont think it autoformats anything. Black, on the other hand, is an autoformatter and automatically format files to conform to PEP8. See [here](https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/the_black_code_style.html). These two things can co-exist, but flake8 is _almost_ redundant if we use black.

> * Run sphinx with warnings set to fail the build

> Some niceties that can probably be broken out into a different process: it would be awesome if we could execute all of our tutorial jupyter notebooks and verify they work on each build. It would likewise be awesome if we could store this output .ipynb file somewhere for pretty rendering of some sort, especially if we can make use of the built-in Github viewer (so we don't have to manage any of our own servers for it).

Yes. The nbsphinx extension for sphinx will run and store outputs for notebooks. I see that the topologic just points to the folder in github with notebooks but doesn't appear to rerun them every build. I think it would be better to serve it on the documentation site like graspy did rather than having to deal with github rendering notebooks. Like @bdpedigo said, its a hit or miss when using github. Do you have an idea on where/how to host the documentation website?
 
Another potential step: we use codecov, which I personally think is very useful when writing code to see which parts are covered by my tests. I advocate for this addition in the pipeline (some sort of coverage testing. doesn't have to be codecov).

issue.title: Proposal: have black run prior to pytest in CI

labels.name: pkg
labels.description: related to package management, github, travis, etc.

issue.body:
- People often forget to run black
- tests can take 15-20 mins sometimes
- only after this wait, black will run and fail
- then people realize, then they push blacked files
- then they have to wait another 15-20 for the tests again
- could have black run and then if it fails, stop pytest run on Travis or whatever CI we end up using

body:
> flake8 is a linter and just shows you where there are style issues. I dont think it autoformats anything. Black, on the other hand, is an autoformatter and automatically format files to conform to PEP8. See here. These two things can co-exist, but flake8 is almost redundant if we use black.

That's fair, but in some ways it's nice to just use flake8 to bomb if there is a style issue and then the user can use black or whatever they want to do the formatting.

I'm only "pro" flake8 because I already know there are no downstream dependencies of it that are GPLv3, and I haven't done that diligence toward black yet.  I'll do that soon though - I'm totally open to it, just want to make sure we keep legal happy.

> Another potential step: we use codecov, which I personally think is very useful when writing code to see which parts are covered by my tests. I advocate for this addition in the pipeline (some sort of coverage testing. doesn't have to be codecov).

Fair, I'll edit my top issue to include code coverage too

I also want to make sure we run our tests on all of the OSes and versions of Python we support.  Getting #277 and #430 in is a super high priority for us because we use basically 3.8 only.  A few of us have even started using 3.9b so... yeah.  I'm going to push to be aggressive on supporting the latest pythons from 3.6 up!

in #468 @bdpedigo brought up the benefits of running the various steps (black, pytest, codecoverage, etc) separately so it's easy to see what failed. This is a super valuable thing, but I think even in a single build pipeline we get each step printing in github's PR view. I'm going to attach a screenshot of what it's doing for graspologic-native (still private until I figure out how to sign builds with MSFT's keys, but showing you this won't be a problem): So in this screenshot each thing is a separate task. So basically what I'll do when I create the build is force the build to fan-out with multiple executors for the things that are platform/version independent (black and sphinx and... maybe coverage?), then pytest we should def. run on the matrix of Python3.6-3.8 and macOS, Linux, Windows. I think that should work well enough, right?
